text:
Yeah, I would like to talk
about the Black Hawk Down.

So this was-- it was in
October today in 1993.

And so a couple of
months prior, we

had a huge JSOC exercise at
Fort Bliss, Texas in El Paso.

And so all of the rangers, all
of the other special mission

units, all of the
helicopter units

were out there, all
the fixed-wing units--
just a huge exercise.

In the middle of the
exercise, they had an alert.

And a large portion
of the force,
today we need to go back home.

You're going to get
alerted to go to Somalia
to kind of sort things there.

And if you go back and
look at the history there,

we intervened to provide
humanitarian assistance

to a starving population and
helping the UN bring food

in to feed a
famine-riddled population.

Over time, there
are people there,

these warlords, who
were politically

empowered by if they
could hand out the food,

rather than us
handing out the food.

And so they were intercepting
these food shipments.

And we said, hey, we need to
get these folks out of here.
So that's when they activated.

So we were on
exercise in El Paso.

All of a sudden, the
next day a bunch of them
leave and go home.
And we didn't see them again.
And on October 3rd of
at Hurlburt Field, Florida.

And our squadron commander said,
hey, I to call everybody in.
We have a commander's call.

He brought us all
in a room like this

and said, hey, just
so you know, we've

got a tough fight going
on in Somalia right now.

And he kind of outlined
at that point--
they were about

about what was happening
on the ground there.

And it was just-- it
was tragic because we
knew all these folks.

And as Joe said, just some
tremendous personal courage

and selflessness
there that kind of

set the standard for
the JSOC community.

And we stand on the shoulders of
those who are who fought there.

But I appreciate-- Joe,
appreciate you bringing that
up.
It's a big day.

So Scott, the number we've
all been thinking about--
[LAUGHTER]
I think you--
What--
[LAUGHTER]

What is the
significance of 1.47?

And also, why did you
decide to go into service?

Why did you decide
to go to the academy

and serve our
country for decades?

I try not to focus on
the 1.47, but thank you
for bringing that up.

So I grew up in Kentucky
in a very small town--

probably 3,000 people
in the entire county.

I went to school
from kindergarten

through 12th grade
with the same kids.

Did very well in school,
good athletically,
involved in the church.

I was a big fish in
a small pond there.

In my junior year
in high school,

I received a football
kind of recruiting letter
from the Air Force Academy.

I had no idea what the
Air Force Academy was.

I really-- we had no
military affiliation.
I didn't understand it.

But my dad was smart enough
to know, hey, that's free.

You need to apply
and pursue that.
So I did.
I pursued it.

And I didn't ended up
making the football team.
I got cut during the tryouts.

But it was-- I was at
the Air Force Academy.
Things were doing well.

So at military
academies-- and I'm

sure it's the same for
all my other military

academy colleagues in
here-- they kind of-- they
want to build the whole person.

And so when you talk
about the whole person,
you want the military side.

You want the
professionalism we expect
from our military members.

You want a strong academic,
intellectual curiosity.
You want to build that.

You want to build
the spiritual side.

You want to have
something in your core

that's going to sustain
you, and the athletic side.

And so what they do is they give
you way too many things to do,

and it's an exercise
in prioritization

the first semester, or first
year there, particularly.

So having not grown
up every day on a farm

and getting yelled at from
waking up to going to bed,

I said, hmm, I need
to focus a little more
on the military side.
So I did.

And at the end of
my first semester,
my shoes were impeccable.

You could hold
your hand over them
and see-- it's like a mirror.
You could see all your fingers.
My belt buckle-- incredible.
Not a stain on my uniform.

Everything was
perfectly lined up.
Athletically, I was doing fine.
Spiritually, I was doing fine.

Academically, I thought,
hey, things are going good.

I always do-- I always tend
to pull it out when the
when the exam is on the line.
I'll be OK here.

And so then you leave home for
your first Christmas break.

When I come back after Christmas
break, in my room there

they have your report
card sitting on your desk.

And I was surprised to find I
had a 1.47 grade point average
after my first semester.

So I immediately-- this is
back in the payphone days.

I immediately got
out in the hall,

walked straight down
the hall to the phone
bank, the payphone bank.

Called my dad, said,
they're kicking me out.
Please enroll me somewhere.

I'll probably be home in
a couple of weeks here.
This experiment is over.

Start talking to
schools, which he did.

So that was my
inauspicious beginning.
Yeah, that's crazy.

From 1.47 to the
best of the best.

So talk about then--
somewhere along the line,

you didn't know anything--
you know, an F-16 from an F-14
back then.

But then somehow, you
got into helicopters.

And kind of talk about that
transition into that interest.
Yeah.

So, again, when you go out
to the Air Force Academy,
a lot of people come there.
They want to fly.

They grew up in a
military family.
They really wanted to fly.
This was the best way to go.
I didn't want to.
I wanted it for the education.
It was a free education.

And I had no
intention of flying.

I had no intention of
making a career out of it.

And I remember
early there, they're

kind of showing us this
motivational slideshow of all
these airplanes.

And guys are going
F-16, B-52, B-1.

I'm like, I don't know
any of this stuff.
I'm never going to cut it here.

But every summer,
they would send us off

to an to an air force base
for two to three weeks

to give us a break and
to let us know, hey,

it's not always going
to be like this.

There is life after
the Air Force Academy.

And so in 1985, I went to
Hurlburt Field, Florida,

in Fort Walton Beach, which is
the home of all of Air Force

special operations, and
spent three weeks there

flying on helicopters,
flying on AC-130 gunships,

hanging out with our
special tactics personnel,
and I loved it.
And I came back--

I say, this is
what I want to do.
I want to fly helicopters.

And so I come back
to the academy.

I tell my chain
of command there,

I think I've found
my calling here.
I want to fly helicopters.
Like, stop.

You do not want to
fly helicopters.

And they said, if you describe
the Air Force as a target,

the center of the target here
is like a fighter or a bomber.
You're putting steel on target.
You're taking it to the enemy.

The helicopter's kind of
out there in the periphery.
It's like a corollary effort.
We don't appreciate it.
You won't get promoted.

It's just not the-- we just
don't care about helicopters.
And I said, well, I don't care.

I don't plan on making
it a career anyway.

And I'd rather enjoy
my day-to-day life
while I'm serving.

And I'll bloom more
where I'm planted,

if you plant me somewhere
where I'm passionate about.

And so they acquiesced and
sent me to helicopters.
And the rest is history.
But I loved it.

So that's-- the piece
out there, I guess,

is don't listen
to the naysayers.

Kind of, if people
are telling you,

you don't want to do this--
if your passion is there.
pursue it.

And Scott, as you
know, my husband
has served as a US Navy Seal.

And in the special
ops community,

we often talk about
mastering the basics in order

to become proficient
at your craft.
How have you thought about that?
What are your thoughts on that?
We think about it all the time.

So in the military
vernacular, we talk about
shoot, move, communicate.

And if you look at the way
the force shoots, moves,

and communicates over
time, the shooting

is pretty good, and
the-- very good.

And I'd say from the
JSOC perspective,

we have the best
shooters in the world.

But the equipment
they're using is still
your basic rifle, basic weapon.

When you look at how we
move, that's changed a lot.

We move faster-- different
types of airframes,
different types of vehicles.

When you look at
how we communicate,

that has gotten more
and more complex.

When you talk about
everything out

there in the electromagnetic
spectrum-- how do we navigate?
How do we talk to others?

How do we maintain
situational awareness?

So that has been a huge increase
over the past 20 years or so.

And JSOC is asked to do some
very, very complex tasks
and very complex missions.

But when you look at them,
and you break them down,

you can break them
down into basic steps.

And that was the-- when
I first got involved

in special operations,
that's what we focused on--
get the basics down.

And if you get the basics
down of flying a helicopter

and being able to put it
precisely in the position where

the ground team wants
you to go, and point

the tail right where
they want them to go.
And then you do that at night.

And then you do it in very,
very reduced visibility
and very, very poor weather.

And then you do it with
people shooting at you, that
raises the complexity level.
But you learn those basics.

And it was telling
to me when I would

go out and run the
obstacle course with some

of our special mission
units at Fort Bragg

and just watch the way they
approach the obstacle course.

Obstacle courses are a pretty
common thing for the military.

But these guys approach it every
time-- how can I improve this?

How about if I put
my left hand here

on this obstacle instead
of my right hand?

What if I lead
with my left foot?
How can I shave off

here on this obstacle, which
will accumulate over the course

and maybe save me
three or four seconds?

Seconds and minutes make
a difference in combat.

And so it was amazing
to me to watch our force

in action pulling off
some heroic missions.

But it's a series of basic
tasks that they string together
like nobody else can do.

So, again, mastering
the basics should

be the key for any discipline
in which you're involved in.
Yeah.
That's such a good segue.

I mean, we've been
working with me

on investing for the
last two years now.

And you talk about
derisking risk.

Obviously, what you used to do
was the highest risk endeavor.

Investing has risk--
a different origin,

but the same approach
to planning and detail.
Talk about how that translates.

You know, my view of the special
operations community before I

got into it, I'm
like, hey, these guys

are hanging it out there every
night, just taking huge risk,

probably invading countries
I've never heard of all the time
and nobody knows about it.

But when you-- when I
got there and started

to work with the force,
it's not that way at all.

We never entered a mission
with our fingers crossed.

We were never concerned about,
Can we get lucky tonight?

We knew what was
going to happen.

We built the plan, and
we call it the base plan.

Here's the plan we
want to execute.

And then you start going
through contingencies.

What happens if we
lose a helicopter here?

What happens if two
helicopters break?

What if they break in
route and you have to land?

What happens if the
enemy comes here?

They respond at a different
time with more firepower
than we prepared for?

And we walk through that ad
nauseam to an exhaustive level.

And then we do what we
call a ROC drill, which
is a Rehearsal of Concept.

And you will lay out--
we'll build a model here

on the ground, and
you walk through it.

And you'd say, I'm
flying this helicopter.

Here's where I'm going
to come in and land.

And everybody knows exactly
what you're going to do.

And, again, when things
go wrong on a target,

and they always do, you're ready
for it and you're prepared.
So there's a ton of risk.

But, again, it's the basics
and considering that risk

before you launch that
makes this team successful.

And Scott, how has the
special ops community

and how operations
are conducted,

how has that changed over
the last several years,

especially over the
course of the war?
Yeah.
So big change.

So after 9/11, that
was kind of the heyday
of special operations.

We were called and asked
to do a lot of things.

And we did do a lot of things
and worked pretty hard.

But there are some things
we call the soft truths.

Here are some of
the hard principles
of special operations forces.

Number one is humans are
more important than hardware.
It's not about the equipment.

It's about the person
operating the equipment

and making sure they've been
through the right screening,

they have the level
of grit we want
and the level of leadership.

And number two is quality is
more important than quantity.

This is not something
you can mass produce.

And you can't produce them
after emergencies occur.

So after 9/11, the demand
on the force was high.

We didn't want to lower the
standards because that's
what makes us special.

And so we started working
harder and harder and harder.

But that was a-- it was
a huge demand of force.
We asked a lot of our people.
Now we're changing again.

It's less counterinsurgency
and counterterrorism.

It's more about, What do we
do against some of our more
sophisticated adversaries?

And there's a role for
SOF in there as well.

But we're always
adapting, trying

to be the most effective and
most valuable for the nation
as we can be.
Yeah.

This is a good
transition to kind

of like-- we talked
about the changing
nature of modern warfare.

And I think there's some really
interesting story arcs you tell
that are really interesting.
Yeah.
So, again, same class as Joe.

I'm not sure how it
was at West Point.

But every semester in our book
issue at the Air Force Academy,

we had a book called
Soviet Military
Power that was in our things.

And we would look through
it at all the equipment

and how the soviets
were organized.

That was the place we
were going to fight.

And one of my first
assignments they said,

if we go to war
against the Soviets,

here's where you'll
be fighting from.

Your helicopters will be
brought into this port.

You're going to be
flying out of here.
And you studied it all.

And we studied the
enemy intently.

And back then, the enemy
was very easy to find.

We knew exactly where they were,
but they were hard to kill.

In the special operations--
the counterinsurgency

and counterterrorism the
enemy is very easy to kill,
but very, very hard to find.
They're not wearing uniforms.
They meld in.
They're not-- they hide well.

They get support of the
local populace in some areas.

So that was a big
difficult change.
Now as you see--

the way we talk about
warfare now, it's kind of--

the pendulum is swinging back
to a more traditional adversary
in uniforms, that sort of thing.
So that's changing.

Another thing I
would say was when I
was young we were always lost.

If you're on the
ground, you're lost.

And if you're
flying, you're lost.

And you always-- you
have this map book.

You're trying to
piece it all together
in the middle of a mission.

And, of course,
it always happens

at the intersection
of four map sheets,

and you can't get
them all together.

That's where you need to go,
and it's just so frustrating.

And then with GPS and the
inertial navigation systems,

after a while you
were never lost.

I knew exactly where
I was all the time.

I could put you in the
back of my helicopter

precisely where you wanted to
go at precisely the time you
wanted to get there.
And so that was a big change.

And then that's
changing now, too.

The electromagnetic
spectrum is more congested.

Our Russian counterparts in
Syria have erected a jammer.

They've had it on for a long
time, ostensibly to keep drones
away from their camps.
It also jams GPS.

And so we're-- again, the
pendulum has swung back on how
that's going.

And then lastly, I
would say in my career--

and we still
continue to struggle

to do this effectively, is
to fight as a joint team.

And that means merging the
maritime, the land, and the air
into a cohesive fighting force.
And we've done very good at it.
We always have lessons to learn.

But now we're bringing in
the space and cyber domain.

And getting all
that-- we like to talk
about setting the theater.

If we're going to go do
an operation somewhere,

I want to make sure
logistically we're

set up, make sure we have the
right force in the right place.

But I want to be set in
the cyber domain as well.
And so what does that look like?

How do we get set
in the space domain?
So we are thinking through that.

And it'll probably
be folks like you

who help us-- who will
figure that out for us.

But that's some of the
challenges and changes
I've seen.

And Scott, could you
talk a little bit more

about that in terms of
traditionally when we thought

about service, it was
joining the military,
working in government.

And nowadays, especially
because we're not in active war,
recruitment numbers are down.

How can all of us
in this room today,

instead of the traditional
form of service like you did,

how can we contribute to
national security, innovation?
What are your thoughts on that?
Great point.

And that's one of
the reasons I've

joined Paul and the
General Catalyst team.

We talk a lot about
global resilience.

And for the United
States to remain strong,
it's more than the military.

All of our systems in
the United States--

our infrastructure, our supply
chains-- need to be protected,
and we need to fortify those.

And that is not going to
be done by military people.

First of all, we're not as
innovative and fast as we'd

like to be because of
the bureaucratic nature
of the military.
So we're looking to industry.

We're looking to
the private sector.

We're looking to folks like
you to help us figure out

those problems and how to get
after them in a smart way.

When I was the
commander of JSOC,

we were given a
little bit of license

to pursue technology that
maybe wasn't quite mature.

And I loved it because my job
was to make it an unfair fight.

And if I can give a person
a piece of technology

that will help them
out on the battlefield,

or maybe even prevent
us from putting somebody
in harm's way, all the better.

So I think with the
tech that you all

are seeing out there
that's emerging every day,

we can make it even more
and more of an unfair fight.

So I think that partnership
is going to be crucial.

I think that's a nice segue
to our last piece, which

is kind of like leadership
lessons from SOF,

Special Operations Forces,
to entrepreneurship, company

building, and some
of those topics.

Maybe just think back
in your mid-career.

What were some of the things
that kind of helped you get
to that level of excellence?

And you talk a lot about
embracing the grind.
Like, what does that mean?
What does that mean for you?
Yeah.

So it's, again, you have
to get reps and sets.

And so when I first got
into special operations,

I was asked to do things with a
helicopter I hadn't been doing
before, like air refueling.

And it's intimidating when
you're flying a big helicopter.

And if you've
played Call of Duty,

the Pave Low, the helicopter
I flew is in Call of Duty.
What's the prayer?
What was the prayer?
What would you guys say?
It's called the Pave Low prayer.

You know, please, God,
don't let me screw this up.

And when I first got
into special operations

it was intoxicating
because the people

that I got to work with
were the best I'd ever
worked with in my entire life.

And you don't want to be
the one found wanting.
You want to be the guy who--

you look to your left and
right, and those guys are on it.

And I wanted to
be that guy, too.

And so you work at it all the
time perfecting your craft.

And for me it was,
I'll volunteer.
I'll do anything.

You need a short notice
deployment to Bosnia?
I'm your guy.

You need somebody
to go to Kuwait?
I'm your guy.

You need somebody to
fly on the weekends?
I'm your guy.

And you have to
embrace the grind

because you learn so much
in that grind day to day

that you don't realize
until years looking back.

And I'll say even for the Joint
Special Operations Command,

our reputation is not
built on those days

when they pull off
really complex missions.

It's on the days when
nothing's going on.

And you bring a sense of
urgency to your work every day,
even when it's boring.

That's how you build a strong
team and a strong culture

that I think all you
want to do as well.

And what are some other lessons
that you would impart upon,

especially the founders
in the room today,

based on your experiences
in the military,

as we're thinking about
building companies?

One is embrace the
grind, like Paul said.
You're going to learn a ton.
Two is think about culture.

Think about culture
and your personnel.

I spent more time
as the commander

of JSOC talking about culture
and values than I thought
was necessary.

And so just for an
example, three times a week

we had a secure, a classified
Zoom call equivalent.

And we kind of go
around the world.

Here's what's going
on around the world.

And we'd cover
every combat zone.

We would cover our liaison
officers inside DC,

and kind of-- and so
everybody leaves--

that three times a week
you know exactly what's

going on across the world
in this environment.
And I would make a comment.

Look, you hear the
information I'm getting here.

I'm making the best
decisions I can make based
on the information I have.

If you're sitting out
there in this call,

and you hear me say
something that you know

is wrong, key the
mic and tell me.

And so there will be--
it was-- you're never

too young to be the
smartest person in the room.

And there were tons of
times where there would

be a 23- or 24-year-old
who would take the risk

and key the mic--
says, hey, boss,

I think you may not have had
this piece of intelligence.

And I would always
go and encourage them
to bring that up.
So think about culture.

Think about how you
foster communication

in your organization because
maintaining alignment

is hard to do,
particularly as you scale.

It's very cool, I
think, when you have--

if you have seven or
eight engineers crashing

on a product, and you
get this sense of urgency
and you're building it.

But then you've got to--
you grow a little bit.

You hire a human
resources manager.
You hire a general counsel.

You've got some business
development folks.
You've got lobbyists in DC.

How do you keep that
group aligned and moving
in the same direction?

So spend a lot of time thinking
about that because it matters.
Yeah.

We talked to a couple of
your former subordinates.

And one of the things
they talked about

was just this listening,
understanding the other side

first before kind of like
making decisions, which

kind of translates to empathy
and understanding the customer.

Talk about that-- the
story with the well.

I think that was
that was pretty cool.

So there's-- when you
look at a problem,
you develop a perspective.
It's only one perspective.

There are lots of ways
to look at problems.

And this is-- the
story Paul is referring

to happened back in Afghanistan
in the early counterinsurgency
days.

The task was, hey, let's go
help beef up the villages
and build--

make them stable-- they
can stand on their own.
Can we build schools?
Can we dig wells?

How can we help these
communities in Afghanistan

to make them more
self-reliant and resilient?

And so we had one
team in a village,

and they noted that every
day the ladies in the village

had to walk about two hours
to go out and get the water.

And they're carrying
these clay pots,

walking about an hour
or so, hour and a half,

filling up the water and
bringing it back every day.

And so, of course, the answer
was, let's dig them a well.

Think of the time we can save
and help this village out.
And so we did.

We dug a well, brought water
in, and made the village
more self-sufficient.

What we didn't
understand though,

culturally and not having
the right perspective,

was that that was the only
time the ladies in that village

were able to talk
to one another.

Because culturally,
they're in their compounds

with their families looking
[INAUDIBLE] every day.

And so we denied the
ladies of that village

the ability to talk and
commiserate and kind of share

some of the issues
they're dealing with.

So, again, there's always
other perspectives.

You have to take the
time to develop those.

Whenever my staff would
come to me and say,
we've got to do this.
These guys are out to get us.

I'm like, well, what's
their perspective?

How would they
describe this problem?

Because they're
not bad Americans.

They just have a different
perspective on it.

So always take the time to
think about what other views you
might have of the problem.

That empathy piece is
so important in company
building as well.

It's not just, let me build
this product in my room

without talking to
customers, figuring out,

Does this actually solve market
need, actually solve a problem?

Scott, thank you so much
for joining us today.
Joe, why don't you wrap us up.
Hey.
So this is a tech-focused crowd.
Technology is important.
But Scott said it best.

He talked about
the soft truths--
people and quality.

It matters, not just
in the military.
It's in all organizations.
I think JSOC's amazing.

It's got the best
toys, the best tech,

but it's really
about the people.

I remember General
McChrystal's-- remember

the saying, "building the space
shuttle in flight" in Iraq?

And he didn't do
it with technology.

He built it on people,
across all the services,
across the interagency.
I remember another saying.
I can commiserate with Scott.

Remember he said, "decentralize
to the point of discomfort."

You could only do that if you
have amazing people committed,

who know the mission,
who are focused,

who can adapt,
overcome, improvise,

and execute without being
told what to do all the time.

That's not just the three-star
level, with all due respect.
Absolutely.
It goes down to lower levels.
